titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Central America Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by Philip S. MacLeod and Christine Weideman

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 11:04

did.unittitle: Central America collection

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: A collection of correspondence; government documents, including reports, and decrees; church documents;writings; and published illustrated material from Central America (Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and Panama) on civil, military, economic, religious, political, linguistic and social topics.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
The entire collection, with the exception of materials received after 2012, is available on microfilm. Patrons must use FILM HM 252 instead of the originals.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Materials have been assembled from various collections and acquired from several individuals. They include materials transferred from the Latin American Collection Curator, Yale University Library, 2012, 2016.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: The entire collection, with the exception of materials received after 2012, is available on microfilm.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged alphabetically by country, and by date within the country.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Central America Collection (MS 1779). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence; government documents, including reports and decrees; church documents; writings; and published illustrated material from Central America (Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Panama.) The collection is arranged by country, and by date within country. The description of each item includes, when possible, its author, title, place of origin, and a summary of its contents. When an item is a copy of an original, it is arranged by the date of the original. The date field, however, contains the date of the copy itself, not the original. The date of the original is included in the summary description of the item.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though much of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

did.unittitle: Inventory

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection is comprised of materials from Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and Panama. Of particular import are those from Guatemala. These include manuscripts and printed works which can be used to study Guatemalan history from the late sixteenth century to the end of the nineteenth century. There is a handwritten transcript of a late sixteenth century report of an inspection tour made by a member of the Guatemalan audiencia to the cacao growing regions, which includes details of the customs of the native Americans of that area. Documents related to the establishment of the royal mint in Guatemala, and the scarcity of currency include royal decrees, proposals, and reports. Materials related to the move of the site of the Guatemalan capital from Santiago de Guatemala (Antigua) to present-day Guatemala City, include the lengthy opinions of two oidors concerning the site selection, a brief report discussing the new site's advantages, and correspondence which describes the 1773 earthquake, which led to the relocation.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Patrons must use FILM HM 252 instead of the originals.

did.unittitle: Guatemala

Title: "Carta escrita al rey de España por el Licenciado Diego Garcia de Palacio...." Place: Santiago de Guatemala. Description: Handwritten Spanish transcript, with English translation, of a letter to the king of Spain, in which Diego Garcia de Palacio proposes the use of the land route across Honduras to send the soldiers and supplies for the "pacification" of the Philippines. Also included is a transcription and translation of the contract in which the king empowers Diego Garcia de Palacio to undertake the conquest of the province of Lataguzgalpa (consisting of the modern Mosquito Coast.) Contains an introduction by Ephraim George Squier written in August, 1859.

Author: Garcia de Palacio, Diego. Title: "Carta dirijida al rey de España." Description: A handwritten transcription of the report of an inspection trip made by Diego Garcia de Palacio to the provinces of Guazacapan, Izalcos, Sonsonate, San Salvador and Gracias a Dios. Contains detailed descriptions of the cacao industry, regional geography, flora and fauna, the indigenous peoples and their customs, as well as an early portrait of the Copan ruins.

Author: Caño, Fray Augustin. Title: Report on the Beateria de Nuestra Señora del Rosario. Description: Report by a Dominican friar about a home sponsored by that order for the Christian education of the women of poor Indian families. The report also discusses the history of other such houses in Guatemala and other houses of lay sisters associated with the Dominican order.

Title: Royal decrees by the king. Places: Seville, Madrid, San Ildefenso and Aranjuez. Description: Series of royal decrees related to the establishment and regulation of the Casa de Moneda (royal mint) in Guatemala, as well as the mining industry in Central America.

Title: Report on the Mosquito Coast. Description: Report by an unidentified author dealing with a proposed treaty of peace and commerce between the Zambos-Mosquitos and Spain. The report details the history of Zambos-Mosquitos, English involvement along Central America's Caribbean Coast, and proposes defensive measures to dislodge these interlopers from the region and end contraband trade.

Author: Anleo, Fray Bartolome. Title: Arte de Lengua Qichesic.Description: Handwritten bound Spanish transcript of a Quiche language grammar. This copy was made in 1855 at the Imperial Library in Paris from a 1744 manuscript copy made by Friar Antonio Ramirez Utrilla. This copy belonged to the library of Ephraim George Squier.

Title: Notes on Guatemalan Currency. Description: Document resulting from a meeting concerning the lack of currency circulating in Guatemala. Included are applicable royal laws and figures for the production, and the cost of production, of coinage by the Guatemalan mint.

Title: "Luz de barias providencias pedidas por el oydor Dr. Dn. Jacobo de Huertas...." Description: A series of proposals for stemming the illegal sale of silver and ensuring an adequate supply of the metal in Central America.

Title: "Ynconvenientes de hecho y de derecho con que el fiscal de la real audiencia funda el perjuicio que ocasionaría a la regalía de S.M. y al beneficio público yncorporar en el ayuntamiento de la misma ciudad los corregimientos del Valle...." Description: Document which lays out legal and practical arguments for why municipal officials (alcaldes ordinarios) of the capital (Santiago de Guatemala) should not be responsible for administering Indian villages in outlying jurisdictions (Corregimentos del Valle.)

Title: "Papeleta de Guatemala....sobre el establecimiento del estanco de tabaco." Description: Brief note dealing with the popular resistance encountered to the establishment of the tobacco monopoly in Guatemala.

Title: "Fundamentos que tubo el oidor Dn. Eusebio Bentura Belen para el voto consultivo...." Description: Set of documents concerning the destruction of Santiago de Guatemala by an earthquake and the subsequent move of the capital to the site of present day Guatemala City. Included are the lengthy opinions of two oidors of the audiencia regarding the selection of the site of the new capital city.

Title: Correspondence between Phelipe Romana y Herrera and Francisco Mariano Rodriguez de Rivas. Description: Two letters dealing with the income of several minor branches of the royal treasury, including the gun powder monopoly.

Title: "Copia de carta de mi primo Dn. Manuel Fernandez de Villanueva y Armiño, oydor de la Real Audiencia." Description: Copies of two personal letters from Manuel Fernandez de Villanueva to an unidentified cousin. The letters discuss the earthquake that destroyed Santiago de Guatemala and its aftermath.

Author: Arredondo, Manuel Antonio. Title: Report on the relocation of the Guatemalan capital. Description: Brief report in favor of moving the Guatemalan capital to the site selected by the president of the audiencia, which also discusses the numerous advantages of this location.
Title: Petition to the Crown. Description: Petition from the members of the Guatemalan audiencia to the king of Spain requesting and justifying an increase in their annual salaries.
Title: "Relación succinta de la rebentazón del volcán llamado Pacayita." Description: Brief report describing the eruption of the Volcano "Pacayita."

Title: "De lo que se practica en las cajas de moneda en el resivo de las pastas hasta la rendición de moneda...." Description: Report concerning the procedures followed by the Casa de Moneda (royal mint) from the receipt of precious metals until they were turned into currency.

Title: Royal decree by the king of Spain. Place: San Lorenzo. Description: Decree addressed to the audiencia of Guatemala concerning the appointment of Geronimo Robledo as "Fiscal de Crimen" of the audiencia of Mexico, and explaining Robledo's delay in assuming his new duties.
Title: Decree by the president of Central America. Description: Printed decree declaring Realejo, Nicaragua to be an official port staffed by salaried customs officials.

Author: Barrios, Justo Rufino. Title: Letter to General I. McDowell. Description: Handwritten letter on official stationery in which President Barrios invites McDowell to visit Guatemala. Barrios also briefly discusses a plot against his life. Includes a typed English summary.

Title: Autographs. Description: Collection of four signatures pasted on a sheet of paper: Pedro de Aycinena, M. Colmores, P. Buitragas, and Gregorio Juares. On the reverse is a newspaper clipping concerning agricultural production in Honduras.
Honduras

Title: Merl LaVoy papers. Places: La Union, Ampala, Corinto, Puntarenas, Lima, Antofagasta, Mendoza, Buenos Aires, Montevideo and Rio de Janeiro. Description: A collection of forty four items of memorabilia belonging to a Pathe Films newsman, who was assigned to cover President-elect Hubert Hoover's 1928 goodwill trip to El Salvador Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica?, Ecuador, Peru, Chile, Argentina, Uruguay and Brazil. Included are newsletters from the USS Maryland
and USS Utah (the ships Hoover sailed on); photograph caption sheets; lists of ship's officers, newsman and President-elect Hoover's party; menus; invitations; programs for scheduled port landings; copies of speeches by Brazilian dignitaries, a schedule from a Argentine railroad trip, and a Peruvian newspaper
Nicaragua

Title: Authorization by William Walker. Place: Granada. Description: William Walker states that A. Matzdorff and his wife are entitled to passage to New York at the expense of the Nicaraguan government.

Title: Letter. Description: Letter written in French, addressed "Al jefe de los filabusteros en su guard," and signed, Vetesle. Possibly written by a resident of Louisiana. The text contains references to Achille Sigur and Mr. Marigny.

Title: Miscellaneous volume of Enrique Guzman. Description: Handwritten copybook belonging to the Nicaraguan writer and politician, Enrique Guzman. The volume is composed of quotes, poetry, miscellaneous facts, literary passages, linguistic notes, historical information, "memorandum," and writings, some of which he wrote, some of which are drawn from other sources. Most passages are in Spanish, but portions of the volume are in French, Italian, Latin and English. Also found in the volume are envelopes addressed to Guzman, newspaper clippings of poems, and a circular commemorating the 100thanniversary of Guzman's birth.
Panama
Title: Letter of congratulations. Description: Letter of congratulations from French subjects in Panama to the French emperor.
Title: Unidentified photograph. Description: Black and white photo of a church
Additional material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession consists of published illustrated materials depicting people, events, and landscapes in El Salvador and Guatemala.

did.unittitle: El Salvador
Title: "The Cathedral of San Salvador"; "Indians of Guajiquero." Illustrator: Unknown. Publication: The Illustrated London News , page 61.
Guatemala
Title: "View of San José De Guatemala"; "The Guatemalan Troops Saluting the British Flag in the Plaza, San José, 4th September." Illustrators: Unknown. Publication: The Graphic , page 1.
Title: "The British Fleet At San Jose, Guatemala Saluting the British Flag." Illustrator: Unknown. Publication: The Illustrated London News , page 1.
Title: "Antiquarian Sketches in Guatemala, Central America." Illustrator: F. Frenzeny. Publication: The Illustrated London News , pages 532-533.
